job_title: Direct Support Professional in Ottawa, ON
pros:
Depending on the location where you work, the teams can be amazing. When you work with a team that has good collaboration, communication, respect and teamwork, the job was great.

The clients are often great to work for and it can be a very challenging and rewarding environment to work in. I learned a lot.

The training is quite good and the organization prepares you quite well for the job.
cons:
Some locations have poor teamwork, bad attitudes, laziness and toxicity.

Poor management in general. Most of the managers I met were largely incompetent (at least from a team management perspective). CH usually hires managers from within - so the mentality is that if you are a good frontline support worker and are good at providing care for individuals, you must be good at managing a house and a team of multiple people! Which is almost always not true. Management was ineffective, communication was poor, problem solving was poor, involvement was poor. The teams that thrived did so in SPITE of the managers. The teams that struggled, continued to struggle BECAUSE of the managers. One manager I had would show up maybe once a week or two, generally in a bad mood, and generally try to micro manage little things that didn’t matter. Everyone would walk on eggshells until they left, and we’d see them again in a couple weeks! (They managed two locations - were they at the other location 95% of the time? Who knows.)

Instead of firing incompetent, poor performing staff, management would always shuffle these staff to a new location. This was such a problem and ongoing issue that it was a running joke to be “CH fired.” Short of abusing individuals, you could do anything there and have a long 40 year career and not see consequences. (See above for ineffective management comments). This was likely due to the fact that CH was always short staffed and struggled to hire and retain staff. 

The pay was slightly above minimum wage, but not industry competitive at all.

The job is a dead end job. While they do promote from within, 1-3 management positions might open per year, and dozens of eager front line workers would apply. Because it is a dead end job, lots of people hated it and worked there way too long (and created terrible team environments) simply because they figured they couldn’t do better elsewhere. A lot of the team issues came from staff who had worked there 10+ years who just didn’t care anymore and should have been fired/quit.

The hiring process is brutal. Multiple rounds of way too long interviews and paperwork needing to be submitted means that it’ll take 1-2 months for them to hire you after you apply. Chances are you’ll have received 7 other job offers before CH even calls you to do the 3rd interview!

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Toronto, ON
pros: Recent unionization and relatively flexible work scheduling. Management will support you as long as they like you. People who have worked at the organization for a long time will be protected by management regardless of severity of mistakes. The management will overlook older employees not working. As a younger/newer employee, you may find yourself frustrated because you're pulling more work than them. Organization will not discriminate based on race to the best of my knowledge, though this may vary depending on what part of the country you're working.
cons: Though through lawsuits they can no longer discriminate based on religion, gender, sexual orientation, etc, if you're not a Christian you might find a conflict in values, especially with management. Most managers take a very hands off approach and programs will throw employees under the bus if any critical situation arises. There are stories shared amongst employees of staff being critically injured before management even think to act. The pay is lower across the board than other similar lines of work, unionization has barely increased wages.

job_title: Developmental Support Professional in Ottawa, ON
pros: The philosophy of the work is important for this field.  Christian Horizons does champion the view of Person Centeredness for their clients

Conflict resolution within team and management is slow in development.  The company has policies but management often do not implement the regulations.

job_title: Systems Coordinator in Waterloo, ON
pros: Person Centered, great value statement, great core competencies, willing to restructure where needed, works on ensuring the support workers are feeling like they are benefited because they compare themselves with the office workers.
cons: Requires to move a little more from the faith routes in the positions that do not have much requirement of religion, although it is faith-based (this isn't a bad thing), some positions should not require the proof of church attendance or commitment to church because a job can be done well without it. The leadership in the organization could use some investment in updating their education and skills, to a modern day organization and how it is run.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Hamilton, ON
pros: The organization prioritizes ongoing training for its employees. Mentorship from leadership is regularly offered. Self-driven learning is also encouraged and the DSW apprenticeship program is fantastic.
cons: There is a long-standing internal culture that stems from the organization's roots in a Christian community. Though there have been great strides in moving towards making religious faith a non-issue for first level staffing and supervisors, there is some lingering cultural residue that can be noticeable to those who are not from a similar religious background.

job_title: Support Worker in Oshawa, ON
pros: I must first admit from the first day I started at CH,  I enjoyed every  moment of it , the most important part was understanding  the clients, their issues and challenges,  today it's  over 6years and still have the same enjoyment as when I first started,  (1) the pay is good, co- workers are team players  who are  such hard workers , in trying to do their atmost in making the Clients comfortable ,eg proper hygiene, fed , going out into the communities, going on trips , and most of all giving them the Love and understanding  that they truly deserve as individuals,  Oh yes CH has thaught me a lot, and for that I am  truly grateful. This is my point some PM go on a power trip , they tend to forget how they got started , and does show any support  or concerns  for their workers, they sometimes  forget they started the same way as others including myself , and if  some of them could show a little more , maybe compassion  to their staff  life would be so much easier.  This is a Christian Organization  and if that bit of Christianity  cannot be shown to the Staff  who is under you then that says a lot  about where you came from.  CH is a wonderful place to work , but some  PM'S   just try to make it difficult. When we are all here to serve and protect the individuals  for which we  are hired to do.  Thank u CH, for hiring me.
cons: Some people  don't  show up for work , or sometimes always late.
